Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A severe hurricane has left hundreds of people homeless in the community, and the mayor has asked the nun to help organize a major relief effort.
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my telemarketing screen, the clock ticking down to my next scheduled break. My headset pressed tight against my ears, every call monitored, every minute accounted for. The compliance system was ruthless—one unscheduled absence, and I’d be flagged, maybe even lose my job. But my phone buzzed with urgent messages from the convent. The hurricane had torn through our town, leaving families huddled in shelters, desperate for food and comfort. The mayor himself had called, pleading for me to help organize the relief effort. As a nun, I was expected to serve, to be present for those in need, especially now. My heart ached with the weight of their suffering, but my supervisor’s voice echoed in my mind, reminding me of the rules, the consequences. I felt torn in two—my duty to my job, my duty to my faith. My hands trembled as I hovered over the “log out” button, caught between the demands of my livelihood and the call to serve.
